classifications.description: Other physical ignition means, e.g. using laser rays
Fibre coupled pump, e.g. delivering pump light using a fibre or a fibre bundle
Shared pump, i.e. pump light of a single pump source is used to pump plural gain media in parallel

abstract: Sequenced pulses of light from an excitation laser with at least two resonator cavities with separate output couplers are directed through a light modulator and a first polarzing analyzer. A portion of the light not rejected by the first polarizing analyzer is transported through a first optical fiber into a first ignitor laser rod in an ignitor laser. Another portion of the light is rejected by the first polarizing analyzer and directed through a halfwave plate into a second polarization analyzer. A first portion of the output of the second polarization analyzer passes through the second polarization analyzer to a second, oscillator, laser rod in the ignitor laser. A second portion of the output of the second polarization analyzer is redirected by the second polarization analyzer to a second optical fiber which delays the beam before the beam is combined with output of the first ignitor laser rod. Output of the second laser rod in the ignitor laser is directed into the first ignitor laser rod which was energized by light passing through the first polarizing analyzer. Combined output of the first ignitor laser rod and output of the second optical fiber is focused into a combustible fuel where the first short duration, high peak power pulse from the ignitor laser ignites the fuel and the second long duration, low peak power pulse directly from the excitation laser sustains the combustion.
claims: 2. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said excitation light source is remote from said ignitor laser.
3. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said second optical fiber is longer than said first optical fiber and longer than said third optical fiber.
4. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said excitation light source is a laser with at least two resonator cavities.
5. The apparatus recited in claim 4 wherein said laser is a Q-switched laser tunable over a wavelength range from abut 800 to about 1000 nanometers.
6. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said excitation light source is a Q-switched Cr:LiSAF laser and said ignitor laser is a Nd:YAG laser.
7. The apparatus recited in claim 4 further comprising a high reflecting end mirror positioned proximate to an end of said laser opposite an output end of said laser.
8. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said light modulator is a Pockels cell.
9. The apparatus recited in claim 7 further comprising a birefringment filter between said high reflecting end mirror and said end of said laser opposite said output end of said laser.
10. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said beam combiner is an optical fiber coupler.
11. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said ignitor laser is proximate to fuel in an engine combustion chamber.
12. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said ignitor laser is proximate to fuel in the cylinder of an aircraft engine.
13. The apparatus recited in claim 1 wherein said ignitor laser is proximate to fuel in a turbine engine.

15. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said laser light rejected by said first polarization analyzer is split into said first portion and said second portion by directing laser light rejected by said first polarization analyzer through an output coupler into a halfwave plate to deliver selected portions of differently polarized light to a second polarization analyzer which rejects said first portion and does not reject said second portion, thereby splitting said laser light rejected by said first polarization analyzer.

16. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said second optical fiber delays said first portion of said second portion of said excitation light beam so that said first portion of said second portion of said excitation light beam arrives at said beam combiner at a later time than said laser light which is transported by said first polarization analyzer and a later time than said any light not rejected by said second polarization analyzer.

17. The method recited in claim 16 wherein said second optical fiber delays said first portion of said second portion of said excitation light beam so that said first portion of said second portion of said excitation light beam arrives at said beam combiner about 30 to 60 nanoseconds later than excitation light is output from said first optical fiber and said second optical fiber.
18. The method recited in claim 14 wherein pulses of light reaching said beam combiner are spatially overlapped and co-axially propagated.
19. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said beam from said excitation light source is a pulsed beam, having long duration low peak power pulses.

20. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said combined beam has both long duration low peak power pulses from said excitation light source and short duration high peak power pulses from said ignitor laser.
21. The method recited in claim 14 wherein voltage applied to said modulator is equal to halfwave voltage.
22. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said first ignitor laser rod functions as an amplifier.
23. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said second ignitor laser rod functions as an oscillator.
24. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said excitation light source outputs light with a wavelength in the range from about 200 nanometers to about 12 microns.
25. The method recited in claim 24 wherein said excitation light source outputs light with a wavelength of 820 nanometers.
26. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said excitation light source outputs light with a peak power in the range from about 100 kW to about 40 MW.
27. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said excitation light source outputs light with a pulse energy in the range from about 20 mJ to about 400 mJ.
28. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said excitation light source outputs light with a pulse width in the range from about 20 nanoseconds to about 300 nanoseconds.
29. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said excitation light source outputs long pulses of light alternated with shorter duration pulses of light.
30. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said ignitor laser beam has a wavelength in the range from about 200 nanometers to about 12 microns.
31. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said ignitor laser beam has a peak power from about 200 kW to about 250 MW.
32. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said ignitor laser outputs light with a pulse energy in the range from about 10 mJ to about 250 mJ.
33. The method recited in claim 14 wherein said ignitor laser outputs light with a pulse width in the range from about 1 nanosecond to about 60 nanoseconds.
